attributes.title: The relationship between cardiac autonomic functioning and depression among college students: The moderating role of social support

q1.value: The relationship between cardiac autonomic functioning and depression among college students: The moderating role of social support

q3.value:
In response to the U.S. National Institute of Mental Health’s Research Domain Criteria (RDoc) initiative, increasing attention has been focused on investigating multiple units of analysis in understanding different types of psychopathologies (Cuthbert & Insel, 2013). Psychophysiological markers, specifically reactivity of the autonomic nervous system (ANS), has received much interest as a non-invasive, low-cost indicator of autonomic flexibility, the ability to flexibly adapt to changing contextual demands.(Laborde, Mosley, & Thayer, 2017; Kok & Fredrickson, 2010). As a lack of autonomic flexibility has been shown to be an important contributing factor to depression (e.g., Kashdan & Rottenberg, 2010), it is important to understand the specific underlying mechanisms between ANS reactivity and depression. 
Despite the theoretical support for the autonomic nervous system (ANS) playing a role in the development and manifestation of depressive symptoms, empirical support has been mixed. Specifically, it is unclear when ANS profiles confer risk, or relate to psychological outcomes at all(see Stange, Alloy, & Fresco, 2017 for a review). Such mixed findings may reflect (a) limitations in how we operationalize an adaptive ANS response or (b) that individual differences moderate the relation between ANS responses and emotional distress. Thus, the aim of the present study was to test how ANS responses across systems (i.e., parasympathetic and sympathetic) and contexts (i.e., stress and reward) may interact with interpersonal well-being to forecast distinct patterns of depression risk. 
To date, studies have predominately investigated reactivity in the parasympathetic nervous system (PNS), and to a lesser extent, activity in the sympathetic nervous system (SNS) to understand ANS reactivity (Bylsma et al., 2015). However, there is growing evidence that investigating the effects of the PNS and the SNS simultaneously, as opposed to exclusively focusing on one index or the other, provides a more sensitive and comprehensive understanding of the effects of the ANS (Bernston et al., 2008). Following this notion, it may be more promising to utilize composite measures of the ANS to understand its effects on depressive symptoms. In recent years, cardiac autonomic balance (CAB) reactivity, designed to identify biases in the ANS (i.e., sympathetic or parasympathetic responses) and cardia autonomic regulation (CAR) which reflects the level of reactivity more broadly (i.e., high or low reactivity) have been proposed as more comprehensive indices of emotional distress, as opposed to examining markers of the PNS and SNS in isolation (Byslma et al., 2015; Cohen et al., 2020). 
In addition to predominately relying on sole measures of the ANS, studies regarding ANS reactivity and depressive symptoms have primarily only examined ANS reactivity under stressful contexts (e.g., Gentzler et al., 2009). However, congruent with a RDoC and developmental psychopathology perspective (Franklin, Jamieson, Glenn, & Nock, 2015), research increasingly suggests the importance of investigating multiple pathways that may lead to psychological distress. For depression, reactivity to reward, in addition to reactivity to stress, may be necessary for a comprehensive understanding of depression risk (Pizzagalli, 2014; Luyten & Fonagy, 2018). Importantly, past research investigating comprised measures of ANS reactivity found different reactivity profiles under stressful and rewarding tasks, in that CAB reactivity was found to be reflective of adaptive responsiveness to stress, whereas CAR reactivity was associated with greater engagement response to stimuli during a reward task (Bylsma et al., 2015; Kreibig et al., 2012). Therefore, examining ANS responses under both a stress task and a reward task may help elucidate the relationship between ANS reactivity and depression. 
Finally, it is important to note that most research on the ANS have investigated the main effects of the ANS without consideration of possible moderating variables. Contemporary transaction models emphasize that vulnerabilities and risk factors operate at multiple levels of analysis and suggest the importance of considering interactions across different levels to confer psychopathological outcomes (e.g., Beauchaine & Gatzke-Kopp, 2012). Of interest, the polyvagal theory proposes that the ANS may be highly interrelated with an individual’s responses to environmental cues, as the same brain circuits involved in regulating vagal activity play an important role in an individual’s engagement with their social environment, including eye gazing, hearing the human voice, and making appropriate facial and head gestures (Porges, 2007). These findings may suggest that behavioral consequences stemming from ANS profiles (e.g., depressive symptoms) may be highly dependent on how responsive one’s environment is. Thus, it may be most promising to examine how social processes may moderate the relationship between ANS reactivity and depressive symptoms.
A wealth of research has demonstrated the importance of social support, and the protective role it plays against depression in youth (see Lakey & Cronin, 2008 for a review). However, similar to the ANS literature, inconsistencies with regard to the operationalization of social support yields mixed results regarding different models of social support, limiting our understanding of the specific conditions under which social support is more or less strongly operative (see Rueger et al., 2016). Based on previous findings that perceived support provides is more strongly related to depression than enacted support (Chu et al., 2010), a clearer understanding of the relationship between social support and depressive symptoms may be possible by further differentiating between facets of perceived social support. Following this notion, the present study aimed to answer the following research questions:
(1) What indices best measure physiological reactivity under stressful and rewarding contexts?
(2) What types of perceived social support serve as the strongest protective factors against depressive symptoms for individuals with different profiles of stress and reward reactivity?

q4.value:
(1)	What indices best measure physiological reactivity under stressful and rewarding contexts?
Hypotheses: Given previous findings that biases between ANS branches (i.e., CAB) conferred risk in stress tasks (Byslma et al., 2015; Cohen et al., 2020) and levels of reactivity across both branches (i.e., CAR) conferred risk in reward tasks (Kreibig et al., 2012), we hypothesize that CAB reactivity during a stress task and CAR reactivity during a reward task will be most related to depressive symptoms.
 
(2)	What types of perceived social support serve as the strongest protective factors against depressive symptoms for individuals with different profiles of stress and reward reactivity?
Hypotheses: Based on prior research that found responsiveness in one’s interpersonal network to play a buffering role in stressful environments (Kane et al., 2012) we hypothesize that appraisal support would interact with CAB during the stress task to predict lower levels of depression, but not CAR in the reward task. In other words, for individuals with maladaptive stress-response profiles, engaging in social environments where they are able to discuss personal issues will be most protective against depressive symptoms under stressful situations. Similarly, we hypothesized that belongingness support will interact with CAR reactivity during the reward task and CAB during the stress task to predict lower levels of depression.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This is a short-term longitudinal design, with baseline assessments, 3-week, and 6-week follow-ups. The current study utilizes a mixed design, including physiological and social support measures as between-subject variables and depression symptoms as within-subject variables.

q10.value: Registration prior to any human observation of the data

q11.value: Data for the current study were collected between 2017-2019. As of the date of submission, the data exists but have not yet been quantified, constructed, observed, or reported by anyone.

question.value: Participants were undergraduate students recruited from a large midwestern university in partial fulfillment of course research requirements.

q13.value: The total sample size for the present study was n = 108.

q14.value: Using the G*Power software program, this sample sizes allows for .95 power to detect a medium effect size of .3 at the standard .05 alpha error probability.

question.value: Physiological indices (RSA, PEP) were measured through electrodes that were connected to the participants using a modified lead-II configuration and four-spot impedance configuration. Perceived social support was measured using the Interpersonal Support Evaluation List (ISEL). Specifically, the appraisal support subscale and the belonging support subscales were used for the current study. Depressive symptoms were measured using the Center for Epidemiologic Studies-Depression Scale (CES-D). All demographic variables were self-report by the participants.

From RSA and PEP, we will compute composite measures of Cardiac Autonomic Balance (CAB) and Cardiac Autonomic Regulation (CAR) using the formulas suggested by (Bernston et al., 2008): CAB = RSAz-(-PEPz) such that greater CAB values indicate greater parasympathetic to sympathetic activation, whereas lower CAB values indicate greater sympathetic to parasympathetic activation; CAR = RSAz+(-PEPz), such that greater CAR values indicate greater coactivation of both the sympathetic and parasympathetic nervous system.

Multilevel modeling will be used to test the study’s hypotheses. A random intercept mixed-level model (Singer & Willett, 2003) will be used to test all of our models. Preliminary analyses will examine whether all study variables adhere to the assumptions of the general linear model. Gender and age will be entered as fixed effects for all models to control for their influence on depressive symptoms. CAB, CAR, appraisal support, and belonging support will be entered as grand-mean centered, time-invariant Level 2 predictors, while time-varying Level 1 depressive symptoms will be entered as our dependent variable. 
	Initial models will be tested to establish the main effects of CAB and CAR for predicting depressive symptoms over time. Specifically, independent models for our stress and reward tasks will be conducted. Indices of CAB and CAR will be entered independently, and subsequently simultaneously, to predict depressive symptom trajectories and depressive symptom levels. If the interaction between time and the predictors on depressive symptoms are significant, but in an unexpected direction, the intercept will be recentered to the final time point to differentiate between a main effect and regression to the mean for the impact of the predictors on symptom levels. 
	Once the univariate relations are established, we will examine the interaction models. Once again separate, but identical models for reactivity to stress and reward will be conducted. Specifically, models including three-way interactions (e.g., CAB(stress) × appraisal support × time) will be examined to predict depressive symptoms. Initial models will test the form of social support separately, but if both are significant, models will be conducted which include interactions with both forms of social support. If findings do not vary as a function of time, two-way interactions (e.g., CAB(stress) × appraisal support) will be examined, and the relationship between baseline outcomes and predictors will be assumed to be consistent across the course of the study. All analyses will be conducted with SPSS 25.0.

q20.value: If the data are skewed, we will implement either square root, or logarithmic transformations to adjust for assumptions of normality.

q21.value: Findings that are significant at p<.05 and achieve at least a small effect (reffect size > .20) will be considered clinically significant.

attributes.title: Age and experience-related effects on divided attention for music
attributes.description:
Extension of Bigand, McAdams & Foret (2000) investigating divided attention in music; using a similar paradigm of error detection for two simultaneous familiar melodies, this study will examine the effects of age and musical training on attentional resource allocation in this musical context.

This is part of a series of studies investigating music perception in older adults, focusing on cognitive functions that may be preserved in order to use them as cognitive scaffolds in the development of a training programme for improving speech in noise perception in older adults.

q1.value: Age and experience-related effects on divided attention for music

q3.value:
Previous research (Bigand, McAdams and Foret, 2000) suggests that young musicians and non-musicians are not capable of true divided attention when listening to two simultaneous melodies but instead either switch their attention from one melody to another, or integrate them into a single harmonized melody, with musicians more likely to use the latter strategy. Research also suggests that listening becomes more effortful with age (Pichora-Fuller et al., 2016) and that the successful allocation of attention can help mitigate this increase in effort.  This study investigates how attention allocation in a musical context is affected by age and musical training in order to identify if and in what context older adults differ from younger adults in their attention allocation and the role musical training may play in mediating these changes.

More specifically, this study will ask participants to identify errors placed in two simultaneously presented nursery rhymes. These errors will be either in the same key or in a different key from the melody, where the former would sound good in context but be wrong for that melody and be more difficult to detect, and the latter would sound bad in context and also be wrong for that melody and be easier to detect. Combined with instructions to listen to only the top melody, only the bottom melody, or both melodies at the same time, these manipulations will determine which of the above strategies participants are employing. If they are switching between the two melodies when listening to both at the same time, they should be able to detect both same- and different-key errors equally well; if they are integrating the melodies together into a harmony, then different-key errors will be detected more often than same-key errors. Instructions on what melody(ies) to listen to will also vary either by block of trials, or at each trial, allowing us to evaluate the participants' ability to switch their attention quickly.

q4.value:
This study tests the following hypotheses:
1. Older adults will perform worse than younger adults in trials where participants listen to both melodies simultaneously, and when the instructions change at each trial; otherwise, they will perform similarly to younger adults.
2. Musicians will perform better than non-musicians overall for both age groups

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This study is of mixed design, where all participants will be tested for each condition (within variables; no counterbalancing required) and participants are divided into four groups (between variables): younger musicians, younger non-musicians, older musicians and older non-musicians.

q9.value: The order of the trials within each block will be randomized, as well as the order of the blocks; see Sampling Plan for more details.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Participants will be recruited by age and musical training, where we are looking for adults younger than 35 and older than 60, and adults with little to no musical training and adults with at least five years of formal training. Participants will be recruited via posters on community message boards (Example: Memorial University Campus, Health Science Centre, Public Libraries, board in public places, like grocery stores or gas stations), and online through social media (E.g. Facebook, Twitter, Instagram). Posts will only be made in public social media forums. Community groups and University faculties will also be approached to help disseminate recruitment materials. The Health Research Unit (HRU) will also aid with participant recruitment by providing a list of potential participants and their phone numbers. This list is curated to so that people on the list are of a specific age and location (e.g., over 65 and in St. John's region or between age 18-35 and in St. John's region). Participants will be compensated for their time with a small honorarium of $10.

In the lab, participants will give informed consent, have their hearing thresholds measured using pure tone audiometry and complete the experiment. In a PTA test, listeners are exposed to a pure tone frequency at 30dB to begin. If they can hear this, the intensity is attenuated in steps of 5dB until it can no longer be heard. If they cannot, the intensity is increased in steps of 5dB until it can be heard. Frequencies tested include 250, 500, 1000, 2000, 4000 and 8000Hz. Each ear is tested separately and sounds are presented through headphones.

Next, the researcher will explain the experimental task, presented using the software ePrime (version 3.0). They will hear each of the four nursery rhymes (Mary had a little lamb, London bridge is falling down, Pop! goes the weasel and Row, row, row your boat) on its own and be asked to identify them to confirm that all melodies are recognized and known. They will then hear two practice trials, one with same-key errors and one with different-key errors and one with instructions to listen to the top melody and the other to listen to the bottom melody. Participants will receive feedback on these trials and their understanding will be verified verbally before continuing on to the experimental trials.

There will be 48 experimental trials divided into 6 blocks of 8 trials, each approximately 15 seconds long for a total of approximately 2 minutes per block. A break will be offered between each block where participants can take off headphones and/or step out of the booth, as this task requires a high amount of concentration. Three blocks will have fixed instructions throughout (listen to top melody, listen to bottom melody, listen to both melodies) while three blocks will randomly alternate between these three attention instructions. Distribution of trials with same-key and different-key errors and with each melody as the top melody will be equal across the 48 trials. Trial presentation within each block and block presentation will be randomized for each participant.

For their final experimental task, participants will listen to the melodies on their own again, but this time containing errors. Correct identification of these errors will serve as a control task to ensure that participants are able to detect errors without the distraction of the other melody.

Once all trials are complete, participants will fill out the Goldsmiths Musical Sophistication Index's musical training sub-scale, a short musical background questionnaire (see project Materials). Participants will be debriefed, compensated and informed about how they can keep in touch with the lab and where they will be able to find the published results of the study. This experimental procedure should take approximately one hour to complete.

q13.value: Our target sample size is 80 participants, or 20 per group.

q14.value: The sample size is primarily based on a practical constraint; it is also the sample size of a previous study with the same participant groups which yielded sufficient power to detect a non-zero, null effect.

q15.value: Data collection will be terminated when target sample size is reached.

question.value:
Observed IVs:
- Age
- Musical training

Manipulated IVs:
- Tonality of errors (consonant, dissonant)
- Attention directions (listen to top voice, listen to bottom voice, listen to both voices)
- Block attention directions (listen to top voice for whole block, listen to bottom voice for whole block, listen to both voices for whole block, or the attention directions will change with each trial within the block)

Covariates:
- Average pure tone audiometry
- Highest melody (for each pair of melodies, they will both be the highest half the time)
- Temporal placement of errors (strong or weak beat)
We will measure hits and false alarm rates in order to calculate d' scores.

We will use multiple linear mixed effects modelling to test our hypotheses. The model will be fitted with random intercepts on participants and random slopes on trials, with (1) the tonality of the error, (2) the meter location of the error, (3) the name of the highest melody, (4) the trial attention directions, (5) the block attention directions, (5) age group, (6), musical training and (7) average pure tone audiometry results as continuous or categorical fixed effects, as appropriate. All variable interactions will be modeled except average pure tone audiometry, which will be only a main effect. A model will be fitted to predict d' and one to predict false alarm rates.

An significant interaction between age group and block attention directions will support hypothesis 1, while a significant main effect of musical training will support hypothesis 2. A main effect of tonality of the error would likely show that out-of-key errors are easier to identify than in-key errors. Furthermore, we expect identifying errors in the top melody to be easier than identifying errors in the bottom melody, and identifying errors in both melodies at the same time to be the most difficult. The meter location and name of the highest melody are included as covariates in case any melody is easier than another and in case the temporal location of the error affects task performance. Average PTA is also included as a covariate to check whether performance in older adults is mediated by simply having poorer hearing.

Follow-up t-tests for any significant main effects will be one-tailed in the direction of the effect and alpha levels Bonferroni-corrected.

q20.value: Hit rates and false alarm rates will be combined to yield a d' score.

q21.value: The two linear models will be evaluated using Pearson's correlation between the model predictions and the data, along with 95% CIs. Alpha is set at .01 and will be Bonferroni corrected for multiple comparisons in follow-up t-tests.

q25.value:
Bigand, E., McAdams, S., & Forêt, S. (2000). Divided attention in music. International Journal of Psychology, 35(6), 270–278. https://doi.org/10.1080/002075900750047987

Pichora-Fuller, M. K., Kramer, S. E., Eckert, M. A., Edwards, B., Hornsby, B. W., Humes, L. E., Lemke, U., Lunner, T., Matthen, M., Mackersie, C. L., & others. (2016). Hearing impairment and cognitive energy: The framework for understanding effortful listening (FUEL). Ear and Hearing, 37, 5S–27S.

registration_responses.q5: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.
q6: No blinding is involved in this study.
registration_responses.q9: The order of the trials within each block will be randomized, as well as the order of the blocks; see Sampling Plan for more details.
registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to creation of data
registration_responses.q13: Our target sample size is 80 participants, or 20 per group.
registration_responses.q14: The sample size is primarily based on a practical constraint; it is also the sample size of a previous study with the same participant groups which yielded sufficient power to detect a non-zero, null effect.
registration_responses.q15: Data collection will be terminated when target sample size is reached.
registration_responses.q20: Hit rates and false alarm rates will be combined to yield a d' score.
registration_responses.q21: The two linear models will be evaluated using Pearson's correlation between the model predictions and the data, along with 95% CIs. Alpha is set at .01 and will be Bonferroni corrected for multiple comparisons in follow-up t-tests.
registration_responses.q25:
Bigand, E., McAdams, S., & Forêt, S. (2000). Divided attention in music. International Journal of Psychology, 35(6), 270–278. https://doi.org/10.1080/002075900750047987

Pichora-Fuller, M. K., Kramer, S. E., Eckert, M. A., Edwards, B., Hornsby, B. W., Humes, L. E., Lemke, U., Lunner, T., Matthen, M., Mackersie, C. L., & others. (2016). Hearing impairment and cognitive energy: The framework for understanding effortful listening (FUEL). Ear and Hearing, 37, 5S–27S.
registration_responses.q8.question: This study is of mixed design, where all participants will be tested for each condition (within variables; no counterbalancing required) and participants are divided into four groups (between variables): younger musicians, younger non-musicians, older musicians and older non-musicians.
registration_responses.q12.question:
Participants will be recruited by age and musical training, where we are looking for adults younger than 35 and older than 60, and adults with little to no musical training and adults with at least five years of formal training. Participants will be recruited via posters on community message boards (Example: Memorial University Campus, Health Science Centre, Public Libraries, board in public places, like grocery stores or gas stations), and online through social media (E.g. Facebook, Twitter, Instagram). Posts will only be made in public social media forums. Community groups and University faculties will also be approached to help disseminate recruitment materials. The Health Research Unit (HRU) will also aid with participant recruitment by providing a list of potential participants and their phone numbers. This list is curated to so that people on the list are of a specific age and location (e.g., over 65 and in St. John's region or between age 18-35 and in St. John's region). Participants will be compensated for their time with a small honorarium of $10.

In the lab, participants will give informed consent, have their hearing thresholds measured using pure tone audiometry and complete the experiment. In a PTA test, listeners are exposed to a pure tone frequency at 30dB to begin. If they can hear this, the intensity is attenuated in steps of 5dB until it can no longer be heard. If they cannot, the intensity is increased in steps of 5dB until it can be heard. Frequencies tested include 250, 500, 1000, 2000, 4000 and 8000Hz. Each ear is tested separately and sounds are presented through headphones.

Next, the researcher will explain the experimental task, presented using the software ePrime (version 3.0). They will hear each of the four nursery rhymes (Mary had a little lamb, London bridge is falling down, Pop! goes the weasel and Row, row, row your boat) on its own and be asked to identify them to confirm that all melodies are recognized and known. They will then hear two practice trials, one with same-key errors and one with different-key errors and one with instructions to listen to the top melody and the other to listen to the bottom melody. Participants will receive feedback on these trials and their understanding will be verified verbally before continuing on to the experimental trials.

There will be 48 experimental trials divided into 6 blocks of 8 trials, each approximately 15 seconds long for a total of approximately 2 minutes per block. A break will be offered between each block where participants can take off headphones and/or step out of the booth, as this task requires a high amount of concentration. Three blocks will have fixed instructions throughout (listen to top melody, listen to bottom melody, listen to both melodies) while three blocks will randomly alternate between these three attention instructions. Distribution of trials with same-key and different-key errors and with each melody as the top melody will be equal across the 48 trials. Trial presentation within each block and block presentation will be randomized for each participant.

For their final experimental task, participants will listen to the melodies on their own again, but this time containing errors. Correct identification of these errors will serve as a control task to ensure that participants are able to detect errors without the distraction of the other melody.

Once all trials are complete, participants will fill out the Goldsmiths Musical Sophistication Index's musical training sub-scale, a short musical background questionnaire (see project Materials). Participants will be debriefed, compensated and informed about how they can keep in touch with the lab and where they will be able to find the published results of the study. This experimental procedure should take approximately one hour to complete.
registration_responses.q16.question:
Observed IVs:
- Age
- Musical training

Manipulated IVs:
- Tonality of errors (consonant, dissonant)
- Attention directions (listen to top voice, listen to bottom voice, listen to both voices)
- Block attention directions (listen to top voice for whole block, listen to bottom voice for whole block, listen to both voices for whole block, or the attention directions will change with each trial within the block)

Covariates:
- Average pure tone audiometry
- Highest melody (for each pair of melodies, they will both be the highest half the time)
- Temporal placement of errors (strong or weak beat)
registration_responses.q17.question: We will measure hits and false alarm rates in order to calculate d' scores.
registration_responses.q19.question:
We will use multiple linear mixed effects modelling to test our hypotheses. The model will be fitted with random intercepts on participants and random slopes on trials, with (1) the tonality of the error, (2) the meter location of the error, (3) the name of the highest melody, (4) the trial attention directions, (5) the block attention directions, (5) age group, (6), musical training and (7) average pure tone audiometry results as continuous or categorical fixed effects, as appropriate. All variable interactions will be modeled except average pure tone audiometry, which will be only a main effect. A model will be fitted to predict d' and one to predict false alarm rates.

An significant interaction between age group and block attention directions will support hypothesis 1, while a significant main effect of musical training will support hypothesis 2. A main effect of tonality of the error would likely show that out-of-key errors are easier to identify than in-key errors. Furthermore, we expect identifying errors in the top melody to be easier than identifying errors in the bottom melody, and identifying errors in both melodies at the same time to be the most difficult. The meter location and name of the highest melody are included as covariates in case any melody is easier than another and in case the temporal location of the error affects task performance. Average PTA is also included as a covariate to check whether performance in older adults is mediated by simply having poorer hearing.

Follow-up t-tests for any significant main effects will be one-tailed in the direction of the effect and alpha levels Bonferroni-corrected.

attributes.title: Evaluating Natural Language Understanding through Reddit Advice

q1.value: Evaluating Natural Language Understanding through Reddit Advice

q3.value:
One long-standing question in natural language processing (NLP) is one of evaluation. The rise of deep learning has led to systems that perform well on traditional benchmarks, that were once thought to measure natural language understanding. Paradoxically, on many benchmarks, today's NLP models commonly outperform humans, though it is a stretch to say that they truly `understand language'.

How can we design better benchmarks? Our proposal is to adopt a generative evaluation. In the dominant paradigm, researchers first crowdsource large static datasets for training and evaluation. The format is typically multiple-choice, to allow for easy evaluation. Instead, we propose a generative task for evaluation. Our research question is how to best reconcile the pros of the multiple-choice task design (such as the topics covered) within a  generative format.

q4.value:
We hypothesize that:
1. Today's state-of-the-art machine learning models do worse than humans at generating advice for reddit forums.
2. The effect of (1) can be measured using Mechanical Turk Workers to rate advice. The workers might also be helpful at picking up on specific problems with the machine learning model's generations.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
Attached is a template that will be shown to workers. Workers will be given a collection of HITs (microtasks). Each HIT will have a context, written by a user on reddit, as well as two advice passages. One is written by a human, the other by a machine, but this isn't mentioned to the workers. The worker must say which piece of advice is the most helpful overall and pick some options about the worse piece of advice.

Afterwards, we can use the worker data to compare how well the machine output was preferred. We could measure this in terms of accuracy. The flexibility of this approach allows us to also vary the machine learning models used and compare the effect across models.

q9.value: Each HIT has two pieces of advice: A and B. One of these is human-written and the other is machine-written. Which is which is randomized for each HIT.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: I will collect data on Amazon Mechanical Turk. Recruitment happens naturally (as my account is popular with workers). The payment is in flux now but I'll try to pay at least $15/hour. Subjects will be selected based on how well they do on a qualifying test. I'd like their answers to generally match that of an expert (me).

q13.value: The sample size will depend on the number of models studied, but likely each round of evaluation will include 500 pieces of advice, with 3 workers rating each piece of advice.

q14.value: 500 seems standard in our field, however, we could easily increase or decrease this.

q15.value: We have fine-grained control over the exact sample size.

question.value: The machine learning model in question
Whether the user prefers the machine's advice, as well as why they made their decision.
Accuracy (we don't use statistical models in our field)

attributes.title: Highly mindful: a randomized controlled trial exploring the individual and additive effects of modafinil and mindfulness

q1.value: Highly mindful: a randomized controlled trial exploring the individual and additive effects of modafinil and mindfulness

q2.value: Emily Thomas, Tom Freeman, Michael Bloomfield, Sunjeev Kamboj

q3.value:
Mindfulness has been demonstrated as a useful therapeutic tool, and after having been incorporated into many types of therapy, has proven to be useful to reduce symptomology in a range of disorders, and generally increase well-being – particularly after longer-term training (such as mindfulness-based stress reduction, Davidson et al., 2003). However, much like other longer-term behavioural therapies, attrition rates are found to be as high as 38% (Arch et al., 2013), and current data demonstrate limited effectiveness for persons with a current diagnosis of some disorders (e.g. Strauss et al., 2014). Motivational and attentional difficulties may also get in the way of successful engagement, as well as cognitive patterns which seem naturally counter to the approach of mindfulness (e.g. avoidance as opposed to paying attention to one’s experiences/thoughts). Additionally, symptoms of attentional disorders, anxiety and depression correlate negatively with trait mindfulness (Smalley et al., 2009, Keith et al., 2017), demonstrating that persons suffering from these disorders may be starting off at a disadvantage compared to a healthy sample before even beginning a mindfulness or similar programme.  

One way of approaching this issue is to combine behavioural and pharmacological approaches: just as drugs such as modafinil have been used to enhance ‘vigilance’, it may be useful to pair modafinil with a short-term mindfulness intervention in the early phases of mindfulness treatment. We recently tested this concept in a randomized controlled experiment testing the effects of a mindfulness (versus relaxation control) strategy and modafinil (versus placebo; Thomas et al., in prep). We demonstrated that modafinil (compared to placebo) increased state mindfulness, as well as improving engagement with both behavioural strategies (both during the first practice in the lab and time spent practicing in the week following the lab session). In that study, the behavioural strategies produced only limited differential effects (on heart rate variability), indicating increased parasympathetic activity following brief mindfulness training, but equivalent increases in state mindfulness.  

 

Here, we seek to replicate these findings. However, instead of using only a self-report (state) measure of mindfulness as in our previous study, the active strategy in the current study will be a validated breath counting task, which serves as both the mindfulness exercise, and as a behavioural measure of mindfulness ‘performance’. We are also using a control strategy condition (arithmetic) which we believe is less likely to unintentionally produce mindfulness-like effects, allowing differential strategy effects to emerge more clearly.

q4.value:
1.  Modafinil will increase state mindfulness and sustained attention, and decrease mind-wandering compared to placebo. 

  2.  Mindfulness will enhance state mindfulness, sustained attention, parasympathetic activity (increased RMSSD, HRV) and decrease mind-wandering compared to the control task 

   3.  Modafinil will increase the effects of mindfulness on: state mindfulness, sustained attention and mind-wandering. 

   4.  Participants who receive modafinil will spend longer ‘self-’practicing the task they learnt in the week after the lab session compared to those who received placebo.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)
Personnel who analyze the data collected from the study are not aware of the treatment applied to any given group.

q7.value: To ensure blinding of the researcher to the task type (BCT/arithmetic), a second researcher will be present only to set up that task and ensure the participant’s comprehension of the instructions. This second researcher will not interact with the participant or the researcher conducting the experiment.

question.value: This will be way 2 x 2 factorial, double-placebo controlled randomised study with a mixed design, exploring both between- and within-subjects variables. No counterbalancing is required.

q9.value:
We will be randomising at two levels: for drug type and behavioural task. 
The assignment of participant numbers across the four groups will be balanced across gender and number of participants (at 40 and 80). The random numbers used will be created using a randomisation function from http://random.org. 

Drug randomisation: The capsules will be over-encapsulated by researchers that are not involved in any experimental procedures, and before each testing session, will be put into labelled envelopes according to participant number, so that testing remains double-blind.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: We will collect data from 80 healthy (i.e. free from any mental health or substance use disorder, or significant health problems) participants between the ages of 18-50. They will be recruited through the local community and relevant online platforms such as participant recruitment websites. Pre-screening via telephone will verify eligibility criteria, such as not having an existing current meditation practice (no guided or self-guided meditation in the last 6 months, and no more than 20 hours total). Participants who have heart problems, high blood pressure, are pregnant or breastfeeding or any other contraindications to modafinil will be excluded. Participants will be compensated for their time either with money (£30) or course credits for students that are eligible and choose so.

q13.value: We will aim to analyse all 80 participant’s data in the study. Participant will be allocated randomly to one of four groups (N=20/group, with N=10 females/group): Breath counting + modafinil; Arithmetic task + modafinil; Breath counting + placebo; or Arithmetic task + placebo.

q14.value: The sample size was calculated using GPower software, assuming medium sized effects (f=0.2855) in a repeated measures, within-between ANOVA with 95% power, and alpha level of a=0.05. This calculation indicated that 52 participants were required in a four-group design. This is based on the State Mindfulness Scale, which will be measured three times during the lab session. The effect size was taken from the results of a RM-ANOVA on SMS scores from our previous study, which yielded a d value of 0.571, and translates to an effect size of f=0.2855. A test-retest correlation of 0.47 was used as per the findings of the authors of the scale (Tanay & Bernstein, 2013). We decided to use a total sample size of 80 (20/group), to ensure adequate power, given uncertainty about effect sizes yielded from other outcomes.

q15.value: We will stop data collection after 80 participants have been tested, with the exception that there are participants who withdraw their data or do not complete the session, in which case we will attempt to test new participants to replace whole participant data cases that are lost.

question.value:
We manipulate both the type of behavioural strategy (breath counting task or arithmetic task) and drug (modafinil or placebo) in a 2 x 2 design, which results in four groups: (i) Breath counting + modafinil; (ii) Arithmetic task + modafinil; (iii) Breath counting + placebo; and (iv) Arithmetic task + placebo. These manipulations allow for the examination of a) whether a breath-counting task has significant effects on state mindfulness, attention, autonomic activity and mind-wandering compared to a control (arithmetic) task; b) if modafinil has significantly different effects on state mindfulness and these outcomes relative to placebo; and c) whether the combined effect of breath counting and modafinil will have additive/synergistic effects on these outcomes. 

 

Breath-counting task:  

This task was adapted from the task validated by Levinson et al. (2014) as a behavioural measure of mindfulness, as well as an effective training method to improve self-reported mindfulness and decreased mind-wandering compared to controls. Participants are instructed to be aware of the breath, and count breaths from 1 to 9 to aid in maintaining this attention. Participants press a response button once for each breath from 1-8, and twice for breath 9. Responses are recorded on a Biopac MP35 unit for offline analysis of accuracy. 

 

Arithmetic task:  

This task was created by the team as a behavioural control task, and designed to be similarly engaging as the breath counting but engage distinct cognitive processes to those implicated in the mindfulness task. Participants view a screen that shows recurrent simple single-digit additions, and are instructed to complete these additions in their head, whilst pressing the clicker once per addition from addition 1-4, and twice on the 5th of each set. Unlike the breath-counting task, there was no behavioural index of accuracy (sums were completed mentally). 

 

Capsule content: In the active drug groups, capsules will contain a 200mg tablet of modafinil (Glenmark Pharmaceuticals Europe Limited, UK). The dose was chosen according to the demonstration of enhanced cognitive performance in previous studies, compared to lower doses (Turner et al., 2003). The modafinil tablets were over-encapsulated into opaque gelatin capsules with additional skimmed milk powder (Marvel, Premier Foods). The placebo capsules were identical, but filled only with skimmed milk powder. All capsules will be taken orally.

1.    The primary outcome measure will be responses to the State Mindfulness Scale (SMS, Tanay & Bernstein, 2013). This will be measured at three time points during the lab session, and once at follow-up.  

2.    The Psychomotor Vigilance Task (PVT, Khitrov et al., 2014) is another key outcome measure. This will be measured once during the lab session, directly after the behavioural tasks have been completed.  

3.    A respiration belt attached to a Biopac MP35 unit will be used to measure a) the average length of each participant’s breath cycles at baseline, and b) to have a measure of how many breath cycles are completed during the BCT for accuracy calculations. Thus, for those assigned to the BCT, this will be another key outcome.  

Secondary outcomes are: 

1.    Mind-wandering will be assessed using the same task as in our previous study (Thomas et al., https://osf.io/34xn9), and similar to that utilised by Mrazek et al., (2012). This will be completed immediately after the BCT/arithmetic task.  

2.    The International Short Form Positive and Negative Affect Scales (I-PANAS-SF, Thompson, 2007) will be used as an alternative to the full length PANAS. It has a total of 10 items, and has been accepted as psychometrically suitable in comparison to the 20-item version.  

3.    The Five Facet Mindfulness Questionnaire (FFMQ, Baer et al., 2006) will be used to measure trait mindfulness at baseline. Here will we use the 15-item version, which has been demonstrated to hold the same convergent validity as the 39-item version (Gu et al., 2016), thus is accepted as a reasonable alternative.  

4.    The Depression, Anxiety and Stress scales (DASS, Lovibond & Lovibond, 1995) will be used to measure negative affect experienced in the week prior at baseline. 

5.    The Drug Effects Questionnaire (DEQ, Morean et al., 2013) will be used to evaluate subjective effects of the drug during the lab session before the behavioural tasks are completed.  

6.    The Credibility and Expectancy questionnaire (Devilly & Borkovec, 2000) will be completed after the instructions to the BCT/arithmetic tasks are read to measure to what extent participants believe the tasks will be helpful in improving their concentration.  

7.    A compliance check will be completed after the BCT/arithmetic task, whereby participants indicate on a Likert scale (0 to 7) to which extent they followed the task that they completed. 

8.    At the end of the study, both the participant then researcher complete a guess as to which condition(s) they expected the participant had been assigned to. 

9.    A clicker will also be connected to the Biopac unit to record a) the total number of clicks, and b) the number of double clicks made by the participants during the BCT.  

10.    Heart rate and blood pressure will be recorded at baseline, after drug administration (+rest), and after the BCT/arithmetic task.  

11.    Heart rate variability will be measured throughout the lab session using a Firstbeat Bodyguard 2 device.

We will calculate breath counting accuracy in those assigned to the breath counting task, as a function of total possible number of double clicks / double clicks made. Total possible double clicks will be calculated by dividing the total number of breath cycles during the task by 9.

H 1, 2, and 3 – Main effects of drug and strategy, as well as their interactive effects on state mindfulness will be analysed using a repeated measures analysis of variance (ANOVA), with drug group (placebo, modafinil) and strategy (breath counting, arithmetic) as the between-subjects factors, and time (T1 – T3) as the within-subjects factor (3 x 2 x 2 ANOVA).  

PVT (reaction times) and mind-wandering instances will be analysed using a 2 x 2 univariate ANOVA, with drug group and strategy as between-subjects factors. If the mind-wandering data is over-dispersed, it will be analysed using a negative binomial regression.
 
H4 – A univariate ANOVA will be used to explore differences in time spent practicing the BCT/arithmetic task (in minutes) in the week following the lab session, using drug group (placebo, modafinil) as the between-subjects factor.  

Follow-up analyses: 

Significant main effects or interactions will be followed up by Bonferroni-corrected pairwise comparisons.

q20.value: We do not intend to transform our data, unless it shows clear departures from normality, and only if transformations improve the distribution of the scores.

q21.value: For analyses of primary outcomes, we will adopt an alpha threshold of 0.05. P-values below this threshold will be considered statistically significant.

q22.value: Outlying data points (i.e. scores with studentised residuals ≥ 3) will be winsorized in accordance with recommendations of Tabachnick and Fidell (2001), namely replaced by x(highest non-outlier) +1.

q23.value: Based on our previous studies, we anticipate little or no within-session missing data for our primary repeated measures outcome (SMS). Under these circumstances, a general linear model (repeated measures ANOVA) is adequate. If however, there is a substantial amount of missing data (>10%), linear mixed models will be used, due to their superior handling of missing data.

q24.value:
1)    We will explore whether baseline values in trait mindfulness predict the magnitude of change in state mindfulness throughout the lab session.  

2)   We will explore whether the time spent practicing the task(s) in the week following is associated to the change in state mindfulness from T2 to T3

registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to creation of data
registration_responses.q13: We will aim to analyse all 80 participant’s data in the study. Participant will be allocated randomly to one of four groups (N=20/group, with N=10 females/group): Breath counting + modafinil; Arithmetic task + modafinil; Breath counting + placebo; or Arithmetic task + placebo.
registration_responses.q14: The sample size was calculated using GPower software, assuming medium sized effects (f=0.2855) in a repeated measures, within-between ANOVA with 95% power, and alpha level of a=0.05. This calculation indicated that 52 participants were required in a four-group design. This is based on the State Mindfulness Scale, which will be measured three times during the lab session. The effect size was taken from the results of a RM-ANOVA on SMS scores from our previous study, which yielded a d value of 0.571, and translates to an effect size of f=0.2855. A test-retest correlation of 0.47 was used as per the findings of the authors of the scale (Tanay & Bernstein, 2013). We decided to use a total sample size of 80 (20/group), to ensure adequate power, given uncertainty about effect sizes yielded from other outcomes.
registration_responses.q15: We will stop data collection after 80 participants have been tested, with the exception that there are participants who withdraw their data or do not complete the session, in which case we will attempt to test new participants to replace whole participant data cases that are lost.
registration_responses.q20: We do not intend to transform our data, unless it shows clear departures from normality, and only if transformations improve the distribution of the scores.
registration_responses.q21: For analyses of primary outcomes, we will adopt an alpha threshold of 0.05. P-values below this threshold will be considered statistically significant.
registration_responses.q22: Outlying data points (i.e. scores with studentised residuals ≥ 3) will be winsorized in accordance with recommendations of Tabachnick and Fidell (2001), namely replaced by x(highest non-outlier) +1.
registration_responses.q23: Based on our previous studies, we anticipate little or no within-session missing data for our primary repeated measures outcome (SMS). Under these circumstances, a general linear model (repeated measures ANOVA) is adequate. If however, there is a substantial amount of missing data (>10%), linear mixed models will be used, due to their superior handling of missing data.
registration_responses.q24:
1)    We will explore whether baseline values in trait mindfulness predict the magnitude of change in state mindfulness throughout the lab session.  

2)   We will explore whether the time spent practicing the task(s) in the week following is associated to the change in state mindfulness from T2 to T3
registration_responses.q8.question: This will be way 2 x 2 factorial, double-placebo controlled randomised study with a mixed design, exploring both between- and within-subjects variables. No counterbalancing is required.
registration_responses.q12.question: We will collect data from 80 healthy (i.e. free from any mental health or substance use disorder, or significant health problems) participants between the ages of 18-50. They will be recruited through the local community and relevant online platforms such as participant recruitment websites. Pre-screening via telephone will verify eligibility criteria, such as not having an existing current meditation practice (no guided or self-guided meditation in the last 6 months, and no more than 20 hours total). Participants who have heart problems, high blood pressure, are pregnant or breastfeeding or any other contraindications to modafinil will be excluded. Participants will be compensated for their time either with money (£30) or course credits for students that are eligible and choose so.
registration_responses.q16.question:
We manipulate both the type of behavioural strategy (breath counting task or arithmetic task) and drug (modafinil or placebo) in a 2 x 2 design, which results in four groups: (i) Breath counting + modafinil; (ii) Arithmetic task + modafinil; (iii) Breath counting + placebo; and (iv) Arithmetic task + placebo. These manipulations allow for the examination of a) whether a breath-counting task has significant effects on state mindfulness, attention, autonomic activity and mind-wandering compared to a control (arithmetic) task; b) if modafinil has significantly different effects on state mindfulness and these outcomes relative to placebo; and c) whether the combined effect of breath counting and modafinil will have additive/synergistic effects on these outcomes. 

 

Breath-counting task:  

This task was adapted from the task validated by Levinson et al. (2014) as a behavioural measure of mindfulness, as well as an effective training method to improve self-reported mindfulness and decreased mind-wandering compared to controls. Participants are instructed to be aware of the breath, and count breaths from 1 to 9 to aid in maintaining this attention. Participants press a response button once for each breath from 1-8, and twice for breath 9. Responses are recorded on a Biopac MP35 unit for offline analysis of accuracy. 

 

Arithmetic task:  

This task was created by the team as a behavioural control task, and designed to be similarly engaging as the breath counting but engage distinct cognitive processes to those implicated in the mindfulness task. Participants view a screen that shows recurrent simple single-digit additions, and are instructed to complete these additions in their head, whilst pressing the clicker once per addition from addition 1-4, and twice on the 5th of each set. Unlike the breath-counting task, there was no behavioural index of accuracy (sums were completed mentally). 

 

Capsule content: In the active drug groups, capsules will contain a 200mg tablet of modafinil (Glenmark Pharmaceuticals Europe Limited, UK). The dose was chosen according to the demonstration of enhanced cognitive performance in previous studies, compared to lower doses (Turner et al., 2003). The modafinil tablets were over-encapsulated into opaque gelatin capsules with additional skimmed milk powder (Marvel, Premier Foods). The placebo capsules were identical, but filled only with skimmed milk powder. All capsules will be taken orally.
registration_responses.q17.question:
1.    The primary outcome measure will be responses to the State Mindfulness Scale (SMS, Tanay & Bernstein, 2013). This will be measured at three time points during the lab session, and once at follow-up.  

2.    The Psychomotor Vigilance Task (PVT, Khitrov et al., 2014) is another key outcome measure. This will be measured once during the lab session, directly after the behavioural tasks have been completed.  

3.    A respiration belt attached to a Biopac MP35 unit will be used to measure a) the average length of each participant’s breath cycles at baseline, and b) to have a measure of how many breath cycles are completed during the BCT for accuracy calculations. Thus, for those assigned to the BCT, this will be another key outcome.  

Secondary outcomes are: 

1.    Mind-wandering will be assessed using the same task as in our previous study (Thomas et al., https://osf.io/34xn9), and similar to that utilised by Mrazek et al., (2012). This will be completed immediately after the BCT/arithmetic task.  

2.    The International Short Form Positive and Negative Affect Scales (I-PANAS-SF, Thompson, 2007) will be used as an alternative to the full length PANAS. It has a total of 10 items, and has been accepted as psychometrically suitable in comparison to the 20-item version.  

3.    The Five Facet Mindfulness Questionnaire (FFMQ, Baer et al., 2006) will be used to measure trait mindfulness at baseline. Here will we use the 15-item version, which has been demonstrated to hold the same convergent validity as the 39-item version (Gu et al., 2016), thus is accepted as a reasonable alternative.  

4.    The Depression, Anxiety and Stress scales (DASS, Lovibond & Lovibond, 1995) will be used to measure negative affect experienced in the week prior at baseline. 

5.    The Drug Effects Questionnaire (DEQ, Morean et al., 2013) will be used to evaluate subjective effects of the drug during the lab session before the behavioural tasks are completed.  

6.    The Credibility and Expectancy questionnaire (Devilly & Borkovec, 2000) will be completed after the instructions to the BCT/arithmetic tasks are read to measure to what extent participants believe the tasks will be helpful in improving their concentration.  

7.    A compliance check will be completed after the BCT/arithmetic task, whereby participants indicate on a Likert scale (0 to 7) to which extent they followed the task that they completed. 

8.    At the end of the study, both the participant then researcher complete a guess as to which condition(s) they expected the participant had been assigned to. 

9.    A clicker will also be connected to the Biopac unit to record a) the total number of clicks, and b) the number of double clicks made by the participants during the BCT.  

10.    Heart rate and blood pressure will be recorded at baseline, after drug administration (+rest), and after the BCT/arithmetic task.  

11.    Heart rate variability will be measured throughout the lab session using a Firstbeat Bodyguard 2 device.
registration_responses.q18.question: We will calculate breath counting accuracy in those assigned to the breath counting task, as a function of total possible number of double clicks / double clicks made. Total possible double clicks will be calculated by dividing the total number of breath cycles during the task by 9.
registration_responses.q19.question:
H 1, 2, and 3 – Main effects of drug and strategy, as well as their interactive effects on state mindfulness will be analysed using a repeated measures analysis of variance (ANOVA), with drug group (placebo, modafinil) and strategy (breath counting, arithmetic) as the between-subjects factors, and time (T1 – T3) as the within-subjects factor (3 x 2 x 2 ANOVA).  

PVT (reaction times) and mind-wandering instances will be analysed using a 2 x 2 univariate ANOVA, with drug group and strategy as between-subjects factors. If the mind-wandering data is over-dispersed, it will be analysed using a negative binomial regression.
 
H4 – A univariate ANOVA will be used to explore differences in time spent practicing the BCT/arithmetic task (in minutes) in the week following the lab session, using drug group (placebo, modafinil) as the between-subjects factor.  

Follow-up analyses: 

Significant main effects or interactions will be followed up by Bonferroni-corrected pairwise comparisons.

attributes.title: What is the source of proactive interference in young children’s Visual Working Memory?

data.value: It's complicated. We have already collected some data but explain in Question 8 why readers may consider this a valid pre-registration nevertheless.

name.value: What is the source of proactive interference in young children’s Visual Working Memory?

other.value:
Any secondary analyses:

We will analyze if age has an effect on overall VWM performance, and the difference between the two trial types (PI effect) as well. We will also run a logistic regression to analyze potential changes in performance over trials within each block. 
Additionally, parents will fill out questionnaires regarding the number of electronic devices they have in their homes, which devices are used consistently by adults, which electronic devices are used consistently by their child. We will also ask how many minutes per day they child uses a tablet and how many hours the child used the tablet the night before participation in the experiment (Cristia & Seidel, 2016; Choi, Kirkorian & Pempek, 2018) Lastly, we will ask if the child plays the memory game at home and if so, how often. We will also ask if they play electronically or with cards. With this information we will look to see if prior home experience with either the tablet and/or the memory game impacts the toddlers’ performance.

Data from 10 participants been collected (as of 3/4/2020) but has not been accessed or analyzed in any way. Start date: 2/18/2020. Estimated end date: 12/31/2020.

sample.value: Using G*Power we calculated that we would need to recruit a total of 34 toddlers between the ages of 30 and 42 months in order to have an effect size of d=0.5, alpha=0.05 and statistical power of 80% for our main analysis, the paired-sample t-test (Faul, Erdfelder, Lang & Buchner, 2007).

analyses.value: We will run a paired sample t-test to compare performance in the trials where the images are unique (A trials) versus the trials where images are repeated (B, C, D trials, etc.). If proactive interference originates from a reactivation of previously learned information rather than lingering information from the previous trial, then we expect that performance will be lower on trials where the objects are repeated (i. e. ‘A’ trials) than in the trials where the stimuli are new every time (i. e. trials B,C,D,E,F,G,H,I). In this case, we would expect to find a significant difference between the two phases. If we do not find a significant difference in performance between the two trial types then we will not have enough evidence to reject the null hypothesis, that proactive interference does not originate from a reactivation of previously seen information.

outliers.value:
Participant-level exclusions:
1. Toddlers who cannot pass the test of task understanding: getting 3 trials correct in the 8 training trials (when cards are face-up, so there is no memory demand).
2. Toddlers who complete less than three trials in either block of the test phase will not be included in the data analysis.
3. Toddlers will be full-term with no developmental concerns, eye-movement or vision problems. Toddlers who have an immediate family member with colorblindness will not be recruited for the study. 
4.Scores that are more than 2.5 median absolute deviations away from the median in any direction will be considered outliers and will not be included in the final data set (Leys, Ley, Klein, Bernard & Licata, 2013).
Trial-level exclusion:
1. Trials where neither the left nor the right bottom cards were selected will not be included in the analysis.

dependent.value: The key dependent variable is percent of correct trials when the match card was selected within the response period by touching it on the touchscreen tablet.

conditions.value: Each participant will see both trial types, in an interleaved fashion (within-subject design).

hypothesis.value:
Proactive interference is a memory error where the retrieval of desired information is hindered by interference from already acquired knowledge (Keppel & Underwood, 1962). In working memory, it is defined as the inability to inhibit previously learned information that is not relevant to the current task (Kane & Engle, 2000). The robust effects of proactive interference on working memory were first shown using verbal stimuli in adults (Keppel & Underwood, 1962; Underwood, 1957; Wickens, Born, & Allen, 1963). More recent studies revealed that proactive interference is present in WM tasks using visual stimuli as well (Makovski & Jiang, 2008; Hartshorne, 2008). The results of these studies show that performance on subsequent trials suffers when subjects are presented with stimuli that have previously been presented.
 	Because of these robust effects found in adults, it is important to explore how interference might impact working memory capacity in toddlers or infants (see Zosh & Feigenson, Oakes & Kovack-Lesh, 2013). We are currently investigating how toddlers between the ages of 30-42 months may cope with the effects of proactive interference using a visual working memory task (Hamilton, Blaser & Kaldy, 2020, preregistration: https://osf.io/3eg6h). This task (Delayed Match Retrieval) tests children’s memory for object-location bindings and is similar to the popular game Memory or Concentration (Kaldy, Guillory, & Blaser, 2016). Preliminary results from our study show that the effects of proactive interference (PI) are indeed present in toddlers in this VWM task between the ages of 30 and 42 months.
In light of this finding, it is relevant to pinpoint a potential source of the effects of PI found in toddlers. That is, is the interference originating from lingering ‘residual’ information from the previous trial or from a reactivation of previously learned information that is now in long-term memory? Research conducted using verbal stimuli with adults and older children suggest that the effects of PI are, indeed, caused by a reactivation of information rather than lingering information (Kail, 2002). The current work investigates the origin of PI in VWM in toddlers between 30 and 42 months of age in the same paradigm used in Hamilton et al. (2020).  
Design:
The study will use the Delayed Match Retrieval paradigm (Kaldy et al., 2016) adapted to a touchscreen tablet. Toddlers will see three cards appear on the screen in a triangular arrangement. The bottom cards will always consist of a match and non-match and the top card will always be the sample. First, the two bottom cards will flip over one at a time to reveal images of the match and non-match. The first card will flip over and reveal the image for a total of 3 seconds, then the second card will flip over for 3 seconds. Then both cards will be flipped face-down, then the sample card flips to reveal the image. The toddlers will have 10 seconds to choose the (still face-down) bottom card that they think depicts the same image as the sample. The presentation of the objects will be pseudorandom, such that the match will not be on the same side (left/right) more than twice in a row. 
	The test phase will consist of one single block of 16 trials. 8 of these 16 trials will be called A trials which will always use the same pair of target objects (with the location of the match object (left/right) randomized). In the other trials (B,C,D,E,F,G,H,I) the children will see a new pair of objects on every trial. The presentation of the trials will be such that A trials will be interleaved with B, C, D, etc. trials: A,B,A,C,A,D,A,E,A,F,A,G,A,H,A,I. If the effects of proactive interference are seen on A trials (i. e. WM performance decreases over time) this will provide evidence that the source of PI is indeed due to a reactivation of information from long-term memory and not because of a lingering ‘residual’ information from the previous trial. 
Method:
The toddler will be seated at a table with the experimenter in front of a touchscreen. The task will be explained orally as well as demonstrated by the experimenter.  The parent will be seated to the side of the child and will be asked not to talk or gesture to the child while he or she is participating. The experiment will be run on a Microsoft Surface Go touchscreen tablet and all sessions will be videotaped.
Stimuli: 
The stimuli will be virtual cards that depict images from the NOUN database (Horst & Hout, 2016) that can be shown face up to reveal the images or flipped down to occlude the objects. The objects are pictures of non-objects and will be, therefore, unfamiliar to the toddlers as well as non-nameable. The study will be designed using OpenSesame 3.2.7 (Mathot, Schreij & Theeuwes, 2012). 
Procedure: 
The test session will consist of a directions phase where all cards will always be presented face-up and there will be no time-out meaning the cards will be displayed on the screen until the screen is touched. The experimenter will explain the task and take turns with the toddler responding on the touchscreen by touching the matching card. This phase will consist of four trials and no data will be collected. During the directions phase, if the child speaks another language other than English, the parents will be asked to translate what the experimenter has said. Additionally, if the child demonstrates difficulty touching the screen he or she will be permitted to point to the correct card and the experimenter will touch the card to which the toddler pointed.  
Upon completion of the four directions trials the training phase will begin. Here, the cards will still be presented face up but during this phase, the toddler will have to respond within 10 seconds. If the toddler chooses the correct response three times in a row, the test phase will begin. If the child fails to answer correctly, the training phase will repeat a maximum of 8 times. After 8 trials, if the toddler fails to answer three trials correctly in a row, the test phase will begin, but data from these participants will not be included in the final data set. 
In all phases of the experiment, when the correct answer is chosen, the card is flipped to reveal the match.  Additionally, a picture of Elmo accompanied by a correct-answer sound appears before the next trial starts. If the child chooses incorrectly, the next trial begins without the presentation of Elmo or the correct-answer sound. The responses will be recorded by OpenSesame 3.2.7 (Mathot et al., 2012). All sessions will be videotaped. Families will be offered stickers, a certificate of completion, a small gift and $20 for their participation.

The test session will consist of a directions phase where all cards will always be presented face-up and there will be no time-out meaning the cards will be displayed on the screen until the screen is touched. The experimenter will explain the task and take turns with the toddler responding on the touchscreen by touching the matching card. This phase will consist of four trials and no data will be collected. During the directions phase, if the child speaks another language other than English, the parents will be asked to translate what the experimenter has said. Additionally, if the child demonstrates difficulty touching the screen he or she will be permitted to point to the correct card and the experimenter will touch the card to which the toddler pointed.  
Upon completion of the four directions trials the training phase will begin. Here, the cards will still be presented face up but during this phase, the toddler will have to respond within 10 seconds. If the toddler chooses the correct response three times in a row, the test phase will begin. If the child fails to answer correctly, the training phase will repeat a maximum of 8 times. After 8 trials, if the toddler fails to answer three trials correctly in a row, the test phase will begin, but data from these participants will not be included in the final data set. 
In all phases of the experiment, when the correct answer is chosen, the card is flipped to reveal the match.  Additionally, a picture of Elmo accompanied by a correct-answer sound appears before the next trial starts. If the child chooses incorrectly, the next trial begins without the presentation of Elmo or the correct-answer sound. The responses will be recorded by OpenSesame 3.2.7 (Mathot et al., 2012). All sessions will be videotaped. Families will be offered stickers, a certificate of completion, a small gift and $20 for their participation.

q3.value: Leniency has been framed as a benevolent action toward a wrongdoer. From this perspective, leniency is the “right thing” to do. Conversely, leniency has been portrayed as a failure to apply the prescribed punishment. From this perspective, punishment is the “right thing” to do. Accordingly, from the grantor’s perspective, leniency may be fraught with tension. This study tests the positive and negative feelings that result from being lenient in response to a wrongdoer’s misconduct.

question.value:
This is a between subjects design with 1 factor—leniency—at two levels: lenient and not lenient.

At the start of the tasks, participants will be told that they are to begin by transcribing text from scanned images of print articles and resources on important workplace topics. Participants will then be told that their topic on this task will either be being lenient (for the high leniency condition) or not being lenient (for the low leniency condition). Participants will be randomly assigned into one of these conditions. To prime participants with high/low leniency, we will ask participants to transcribe, verbatim, a scanned image of one article. The image to be transcribed reflects a passage in a “popular press magazine”—created by us to resemble an actual print article—that describes the relevance of high/low leniency. To illustrate, part of the passage reads (low leniency wording in brackets): “Taylor, a supervisor at a national company remarked, “This happens all the time, Managers let [do not let] people off the hook…” The fictional article then provides a list of take-away bullet points, including “Leniency is the act of lessening or removing punishment for misconduct [Not being lenient is enforcing rules for misconduct]” and “Managers do [do not] act with leniency in responding to situations.” Participants will be then asked to provide a short summary of what they transcribed in order to confirm that they understand the text.

Next, participants will be told that we also needed their help identifying the three largest words in a word cloud image that was created from the full text of similarly transcribed articles. In the word clouds we will display to participants, we predetermined the font size of each word. The three largest words in the high leniency condition are “leniency”, “lenient”, and “lighter”; the three largest words in the low leniency condition are “discipline”, “stricter”, and “enforce”.

After completing the transcription tasks for the article and word cloud, participants will be asked to assess other workers’ responses on similar tasks. They will be told that several responses to these word cloud transcriptions have been identified by the system as potentially falling below expected standards. Each flagged response includes the word cloud that accompanied the worker’s response. Each of these responses have obvious errors. Specifically, in each word cloud, the fictional worker will enter two words that were easily identifiable as not being the largest words within the word cloud. We will ask participants to review the word cloud and the three words submitted by the other workers and provide a recommendation on whether we should accept or reject the worker’s response, on a continuous scale. In sum, this exercise provides the participants with the opportunity to be lenient to their peers.

Following these tasks, participants will report their current self-conscious emotions, followed by their current level of engagement and exhaustion. Lastly, participants will complete a manipulation check of leniency and provide their demographics. At the conclusion of the experiment, participants will be provided with a debriefing statement.

q9.value: We will use the randomization feature from Qualtrics to randomly assign participants to one of our two conditions. Thus, we will use simple randomization into two approximately equal-sized groups.
