question.value: Participants will be recruited through an online crowdsourcing marketplace. Participants will be paid $3.00 for agreeing to participate. Participants must be 18 years or older and be native English speakers.

q13.value: Our target sample size is 200 participants. We will recruit up to 240 participants, assuming that our Data Exclusion rules will remove some participants.

q14.value: This sample size is based on the request of a journal editor during the revision process.

q15.value: We will recruit participants until we have collected 240 responses, randomly assigned to two conditions. We describe our two conscientiousness checks in the Data Exclusion section. Extrapolating from the prior application of these checks in our Study 2, we will collect responses from 120 participants per cell to ensure that we arrive at a final sample size of at least 100 participants per cell.

question.value: We will manipulate leniency at high and low levels.

Lenient behavior. Participants will rate their recommendation on whether to reject or accept three different worker responses using a 5-point scale from (1 = definitely reject to 5 = definitely accept).
Pride. Participants will rate pride using Williams and DeSteno’s (2009) 9-item measure of pride (e.g., “proud,” “fulfilled,” “accomplished”). This measure will be assessed on a 5-point scale (1 = not at all to 5 = extremely).
Guilt. Participants will rate guilt using Fredrickson, Tugade, Waugh, and Larkin’s (2003) 3-item measure. Employees will rate whether they felt guilt (i.e., “guilty,” “repentant,” and “blameworthy”) about being lenient since completing the Time 1 survey (1 = not at all to 5 = extremely).
Engagement. Participants will rate the physical, cognitive, and emotional aspects of engagement with three items from Rich et al.’s (2010) measure (i.e., “Right now, I am devoting a lot of energy to what I’m doing.” [physical], “Right now, I am devoting a lot of attention to what I’m doing.” [cognitive], “Right now, I am excited about what I’m doing.” [emotional]; 1 = strongly disagree, 5 = strongly agree).
Exhaustion. Participants will rate exhaustion with Maslach and Jackson’s (1993) 5-item measure from the Maslach Burnout Inventory–General Survey (e.g., “Right now, I feel emotionally drained from what I’m doing.”; 1 = strongly disagree, 5 = strongly agree).
Manipulation check. Participants will complete a 3-item leniency measure that was developed for our research. The items are “I have been lenient to others at work,” “I have given others at work a lighter punishment for their misconduct than I could have,” and “I have been lenient in response to others’ misconduct” (1 = strongly disagree to 5 = strongly agree).

We will use analysis of variance (ANOVA) to confirm that our manipulation of leniency was effective. We will also use ANOVA to assess whether the individuals in the high leniency condition engage in more leniency than participants in the low leniency condition. We will then use MANOVA to test whether pride and guilt differed as a result of the leniency prime.
Using Mplus, we will model lenient behavior as a predictor of engagement through pride and as a predictor of exhaustion through guilt. We will model all variables using scale scores as indicators of the latent constructs.

q21.value: We will use the standard p <. 05 criteria for determining the significance of our hypotheses.

q22.value: We will remove participants who fail both of our conscientiousness checks. The two checks will be the following: “Click the circle under Strongly Disagree” and “I sleep less than one hour per night.”

q23.value: We will use listwise deletion to manage missing data.

q3.value: By integrating the findings presented above, the present study has the goal to verify whether and how the individual’s cognitive resources can predict the accuracy of the memory for a mock crime video. In particular, the study aims to understand how executive functioning resources, specifically Shifting, Inhibition and Updating (Miyake et al., 2000), can be involved in the recall of an event in terms of correct details, omission and commission errors reported. We showed participants a mock crime video1 and immediately after we requested them to provide a report of the event and to answer some questions about it. Ten days later, participants’ memory was tested again. In the last session, each participant was invited to come back to the laboratory and performed some neuropsychological tasks to assess their individual abilities of Shifting, Inhibition, and Updating.

q4.value: We expected that people with higher EF resources exhibit a higher correctness score than people with lower executive functions abilities (Hypothesis 1). We also expected that people with higher EF resources will elicit fewer omission and commission errors than people with lower cognitive resources (Hypothesis 2).

q1.value: On non-adjacent letter repetition effects: A new benchmark for models of letter-order encoding

q2.value: Emilia Kerr, Jonathan Mirault, Jonathan Grainger

q3.value:
There have been recent reports of an inhibitory effect of letter repetition on word decisions in
the lexical decision task (Trifonova & Adelman, 2019), picking up on an earlier report of this phenomenon (Schoonbaert & Grainger, 2004). These letter repetition effects are in line with one particular orthographic coding scheme – open-bigram coding (Grainger & van Heuven, 2004) - words containing repeated letters are harder to recognize since they are represented by fewer bigrams than words without repeated letters. On the basis of open-bigram coding we predicted that nonwords in a lexical decision task should also be sensitive to letter repetitions. In particular we propose to examine two types of nonword generated from the same baseword: 1) nonwords created by repeating one of the letters in the baseword; and 2) nonwords created by inserting a letter that is not present in the baseword. We reasoned that if the processing of a non-adjacent repeated letter is hindered in some way, then this should make it harder to reject a nonword formed by letter repetition compared with letter insertion. On the basis of the results of Trifonova and Adelman (2019) we exclude adjacent letter repetitions (a special case) and distant letter repetitions (separated by more than 4 letters).

q4.value:
Following the open-bigram coding theory, the main directional hypothesis is the following: it
should be harder to reject nonwords in the lexical decision task when the nonword is formed
by repeating a letter in an existing word (e.g., silenlce) compared with nonwords created by
inserting a letter that is not present in an existing word (e.g., silentce). To our knowledge this
has not been tested before, and it represents a test of a strong prediction of open-bigram
coding.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: All participants will be engaged in a lexical decision task and tested in two conditions – repetition and insertion. In the repetition condition, a pseudoword is created by adding a letter already present in an existing French word (baseword); in the insertion condition, a foreign letter is inserted in the same position and in the same baseword. For both types of pseudowords, the repeated or inserted letter is in the same position per baseword and varies across all internal positions. These positions are 2-4 positions away from the letter that is repeated and never in the initial or final position. The two conditions are counterbalanced among participants using a Latin-square design, i.e., two lists are created so that every participant is presented with a given base word in only one of the conditions.

q9.value: Trial presentation is randomized with a different random order for each participant.

q10.value: Registration prior to any human observation of the data

question.value: Data will be collected from human subjects. The inclusion criteria are the following: native speakers of French, 18 to 40 years old, with no history of psychiatric, neurological or language disorders, with normal or corrected to normal vision. Recruitment will be organized through social media announcements, and participants will be offered either payment of 5 euros or course credit.

q13.value: The sample size is planned to comprise 32 participants.

q14.value:
Following Brysbaert & Stevens (2018) estimates for sufficiently powered reaction time experiments, we conclude that the planned study will reach enough power with observations collected from 32 participants – 1600 word observations per condition divided by the number of items per condition per participant, which is 50 items in our case.
Follow-up analyses will include a power analysis of the obtained linear model.

q15.value: Data collection will be stopped once the pre-specified sample size has been reached.

question.value: The measured variables include reaction times and error rates.

The planned statistical methods include linear mixed effects models for the measured variables, reaction times and error rates, with subjects and items as random effects. Possible follow-up analyses might include exploration of the inserted/repeated letter position factor. 
The script for the main analysis is attached below.

q22.value: Outliers of 2.5 deviations above and below the mean will be excluded from the analyses.

attributes.title: "Truth-WIll-Out"
attributes.description: Testing the conditions under which people believe others will come to share their beliefs over time.

q1.value: Belief in a Favorable Future: Truth Emergence or Optimism? - Additional Population

q3.value:
In a recent study, Rogers, Moore, & Norton (2018) provide evidence of what they call “belief in a favorable future” – the belief that, over time, the people around us will come to share our preferences and beliefs. We employ a modified paradigm to disentangle the potential mechanisms behind such a belief. We also present suggestive evidence that the extent to which a person exhibits this tendency about a particular belief can be used as implicit measure of the strength of that belief.

In this additional experiment, we will run the exact same protocol with a population of CMU alumni in order to provide additional support for our hypotheses.

q4.value:
(i) People believe that in the future, as compared to the present, others will share their beliefs to a greater degree (replication of "belief in a favorable future").

(ii) "Belief in a favorable future" even stronger when a person's own belief is objectively correct.

(iii) The desirability of the underlying belief has no effect on the strength of "belief in a favorable future".

(iv) For politically-polarized beliefs, partisans show a weaker "belief in a favorable future" when they believes something congenial to their political alignment, relative to when they believe something poltiically neutral or noncongenial.

(v) People believe others will agree with them in the future more strongly for the rejection of false beliefs as compared to the acceptance of true beliefs. In other words, people believe myths will be dispelled over time more than they believe truth will be accepted.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
Each subject is asked to provide judgements about 12 different statements. The statements vary on 3 dimensions: truth, desirability, and political polarization.

Subjects are randomized into one of two conditions: Item Set 1 and Item Set 2. The procedure is exactly the same for both, but the set of 24 items from Study 1 has been split into two balanced subsets of 12 statements for the purposes of limiting the time required to complete the experiment.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: We will recruit 200 subjects from a pool of Carnegie Mellon University alumni who have opted into receiving research participation invitations.. Subjects will be eligible if they are over 18 and reside in the United States. Participants are not compensated for participation, but are debriefed about the outcomes of the study once analysis has been completed. The study will be posted and completed in early March.

q13.value: We hope to recruit at least 200 participants.

q14.value: Response rates can vary from this survey population, but we will collect data from as many participants respond to the invitation. We expect a response rate of roughly 10%.

q15.value: We will collect all data in one online survey invitation over the course of one week. Data collection will not stop before the one-week period ends.

question.value: We will manipulate which set of 12 statements to elicit participant judgements on. The statements have been pre-tested to be balanced on the dimensions of truth and desirability. This manipulation is only being performed to shorten the length of the survey (i.e. we expect no difference between the two conditions).

For each statement, we ask: 
1. Does the participant believe the statement is true? (Yes or No)
2. What is their level of confidence? (0-100 slider)
3. In terms of the American population, what percentage do they think agree with them currently? (0-100 slider)
4. In terms of the American population, what percentage do they think agree with them in five years? (0-100 slider)
5. Whether or not they believe it, would they like to believe it? (5 point Likert scale, endpoints "I very much would not like to believe this statement" and "I would very much like to believe this statement").

We also collect covariates:
1. Age
2. Sex
3. Race
4. Income
5. Level of education
6. Political orientation
7. Political party

(i) People believe that in the future, as compared to the present, others will share their beliefs to a greater degree (replication of "belief in a favorable future").

Two-tailed t-test: Is the mean difference between "future agreement" and "current agreement" significantly different from zero?

(ii) "Belief in a favorable future" is even stronger when a person's own belief is objectively correct.

Two-tailed t-test: Is the mean difference between future and current agreement significantly different between items on which the participant's assessment of the statement was correct, versus on which they were incorrect?

Linear regression: Is the beta for "correct" different from zero and positive in the following specification? Mean diff. in agreement = "correct" + demographic covariates + political orientation + participant fixed effect

(iii) The desirability of the underlying belief has no effect on the strength of "belief in a favorable future".

Two-tailed t-test: Is the mean difference between future and current agreement significantly different between items which were pre-tested to be desirable and items pre-tested to be undesirable?

Linear regression: Is the beta for "desirable" different from zero in the following specification? Mean diff. in agreement = "desirable" + demographic covariates + political orientation + participant fixed effect

(iv) For politically-polarized beliefs, partisans show a weaker "belief in a favorable future" when they believes something congenial to their political alignment, relative to when they believe something politically neutral or noncongenial.

Two-tailed t-test: On items that participants believe to be true, is the mean difference between future and current agreement significantly smaller for items which are congenial to their political beliefs than for items that are not congenial?

Linear regression on items participants indicate they believe to be true: Is the beta for "congenial" different from zero and negative in the following specification? Mean diff. in agreement = "congenial" + demographic covariates + political orientation + participant fixed effect (we will run two separate models for Democrats and Republicans).

(v) People believe others will agree with them in the future more strongly for the rejection of false beliefs as compared to the acceptance of true beliefs. In other words, people believe myths will be dispelled over time more than they believe truth will be accepted.

Two-tailed t-test: Is the mean difference between future and current agreement significantly larger for items which participants believe to be false than for items participants believe to be true?

Linear regression: Is the beta for "believe" different from zero and negative in the following specification? Mean diff. in agreement = "believe" + demographic covariates + political orientation + participant fixed effect

q21.value: We will use a p-value of 0.05 as our criterion for statistical significance. We will use two-tailed tests for our analyses.

q22.value: We will use an attention check with directed responses for participants. Participants that fail the check will be excluded from data analysis.

q23.value: Any surveys with missing responses will be excluded in their entirety from the analysis.

q24.value:
-We will confirm that the political items in the survey actually are viewed differently by partisans of different political orientations.
-We will confirm that our items pre-tested for desirability and undesirability conform with the results of the pre-test.
-We will examine relationships between demographic covariates (including political orientation) and the main outcomes of interest.

registration_responses.q1: Belief in a Favorable Future: Truth Emergence or Optimism? - Additional Population
registration_responses.q3:
In a recent study, Rogers, Moore, & Norton (2018) provide evidence of what they call “belief in a favorable future” – the belief that, over time, the people around us will come to share our preferences and beliefs. We employ a modified paradigm to disentangle the potential mechanisms behind such a belief. We also present suggestive evidence that the extent to which a person exhibits this tendency about a particular belief can be used as implicit measure of the strength of that belief.

In this additional experiment, we will run the exact same protocol with a population of CMU alumni in order to provide additional support for our hypotheses.
registration_responses.q4:
(i) People believe that in the future, as compared to the present, others will share their beliefs to a greater degree (replication of "belief in a favorable future").

(ii) "Belief in a favorable future" even stronger when a person's own belief is objectively correct.

(iii) The desirability of the underlying belief has no effect on the strength of "belief in a favorable future".

(iv) For politically-polarized beliefs, partisans show a weaker "belief in a favorable future" when they believes something congenial to their political alignment, relative to when they believe something poltiically neutral or noncongenial.

(v) People believe others will agree with them in the future more strongly for the rejection of false beliefs as compared to the acceptance of true beliefs. In other words, people believe myths will be dispelled over time more than they believe truth will be accepted.
registration_responses.q5: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.
q6: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

registration_responses.q8.question:
Each subject is asked to provide judgements about 12 different statements. The statements vary on 3 dimensions: truth, desirability, and political polarization.

Subjects are randomized into one of two conditions: Item Set 1 and Item Set 2. The procedure is exactly the same for both, but the set of 24 items from Study 1 has been split into two balanced subsets of 12 statements for the purposes of limiting the time required to complete the experiment.
